answer_html: Notice that as shown in part (a) the function g is, and has to be, surjective.

Notice that as shown in
{part
(a)} the function \emph{g} is, and has to be, surjective.
hints_html: Start with a choice of sets A and B and functions f and g such that \(g \circ f\) is surjective. If f isn’t surjective, you won, that’s your example! If not, can you add some elements to the set B to tweak your example and obtain what you’re looking for?
hints_latex:
Start with a choice of sets \emph{A} and \emph{B} and functions \emph{f}
and \emph{g} such that $g \circ f$ is surjective. If \emph{f} isn't
surjective, you won, that's your example! If not, can you add some
elements to the set \emph{B} to tweak your example and obtain what
you're looking for?
hints_raw: Start with a choice of sets ''A'' and ''B'' and functions ''f'' and ''g'' such that <math>g \circ f</math> is surjective. If ''f'' isn't surjective, you won, that's your example! If not, can you add some elements to the set ''B'' to tweak your example and obtain what you're looking for?
question: 9 (b)
sols_html:
We showed in part (a) that the function g will always be surjective, this question asks us to give an example to illustrate why the function f doesn’t have to be necessarily.

For example, consider the case where the set A is all the natural numbers including zero: A={ 0, 1, 2, ... } and the set B is all the integers: B = { ..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... }. Now the function f just maps a natural number to itself, so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(n) = n \quad\text{for all } n=0,1,2,\dots\end{aligned}\]

and the function g maps an integer to its absolute value, so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(k) = |k| \quad\text{for all } k \in \mathbb{Z}\end{aligned}\]

Then the function \(g \circ f\) is clearly surjective since it takes a natural number back to itself. That is, \((g \circ f)(a) = a\) for all \(a \in A\).

But the function f isn’t surjective since it doesn’t map to any negative integer (no negative number has a pre-image under the function f). Notice that as shown in part (a) the function g is, and has to be, surjective.

Another, minimal example is the following:

Let A = {a}, and B = {1,2}. Then define

\[\begin{aligned} f: A \rightarrow B, \quad f(a) = 1, \qquad g: B \rightarrow A, \quad g(1) = g(2) = a.\end{aligned}\]

Then, clearly

\[\begin{aligned} (g \circ f) : A \rightarrow A, \quad (g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a)) = g(1) = a,\end{aligned}\]

and thus \(g \circ f\) is surjective.

However, f is not surjective, since \(2 \in B\) does not have a pre-image in A under f.

”Notice again, that g is, and needs to be, surjective for \(g \circ f\) to be surjective.
sols_latex:
We showed in
{part
(a)} that the function \emph{g} will always be surjective, this question
asks us to give an example to illustrate why the function \emph{f}
doesn't have to be necessarily.

For example, consider the case where the set \emph{A} is all the natural
numbers including zero: \emph{A}=\{ 0, 1, 2, ... \} and the set \emph{B}
is all the integers: \emph{B} = \{ ..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... \}. Now the
function \emph{f} just maps a natural number to itself, so

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(n) = n \quad\text{for all } n=0,1,2,\dots
\end{align*}

and the function \emph{g} maps an integer to its absolute value, so

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
g(k) = |k| \quad\text{for all } k \in \mathbb{Z}
\end{align*}

Then the function $g \circ f$ is clearly surjective since it takes a
natural number back to itself. That is, $(g \circ f)(a) = a$ for all
$a \in A$.

But the function \emph{f} isn't surjective since it doesn't map to any
negative integer (no negative number has a pre-image under the function
\emph{f}). Notice that as shown in
{part
(a)} the function \emph{g} is, and has to be, surjective.

Another, minimal example is the following:

Let \emph{A} = \{a\}, and \emph{B} = \{1,2\}. Then define

\begin{align*}
f: A \rightarrow B, \quad f(a) = 1, \qquad g: B \rightarrow A, \quad g(1) = g(2) = a.
\end{align*}

Then, clearly

\begin{align*}
(g \circ f) : A \rightarrow A, \quad (g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a)) = g(1) = a,
\end{align*}

and thus $g \circ f$ is surjective.

However, \emph{f} is not surjective, since $2 \in B$ does not have a
pre-image in \emph{A} under \emph{f}.

''Notice again, that \emph{g} is, and needs to be, surjective for
$g \circ f$ to be surjective.
sols_raw:
We showed in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (a)|part (a)]] that the function ''g'' will always be surjective, this question asks us to give an example to illustrate why the function ''f'' doesn't have to be necessarily.

For example, consider the case where the set ''A'' is all the natural numbers including zero: ''A''={ 0, 1, 2, ... } and the set ''B'' is all the integers: ''B'' = { ..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ... }. Now the function ''f'' just maps a natural number to itself, so
:<math>\displaystyle
f(n) = n \quad\text{for all } n=0,1,2,\dots
</math>

and the function ''g'' maps an integer to its absolute value, so
:<math>\displaystyle
g(k) = |k| \quad\text{for all } k \in \mathbb{Z}
</math>

Then the function <math>g \circ f</math> is clearly surjective since it takes a natural number back to itself. That is, <math>(g \circ f)(a) = a</math> for all <math>a \in A</math>.

But the function ''f'' isn't surjective since it doesn't map to any negative integer (no negative number has a pre-image under the function ''f''). Notice that as shown in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (a)|part (a)]] the function ''g'' is, and has to be, surjective.
Another, minimal example is the following:

Let ''A'' = {a}, and ''B'' = {1,2}. Then define

:<math> f: A \rightarrow B, \quad f(a) = 1, \qquad g: B \rightarrow A, \quad g(1) = g(2) = a.</math>

Then, clearly

:<math>(g \circ f) : A \rightarrow A, \quad (g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a)) = g(1) = a, </math>

and thus <math>g \circ f</math> is surjective.

However, ''f'' is not surjective, since <math>2 \in B</math> does not have a pre-image in ''A'' under ''f''.

''Notice again, that ''g'' is, and needs to be, surjective for <math>g \circ f</math> to be surjective.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{ and }\quad g: B \to A\end{aligned}\]

be functions so that g â—‹f is a surjective function.

Give an example of sets A, B and functions f, g as above such that f is not surjective.

statement_raw:
Let

:<math>\displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{  and  }\quad g: B \to A</math>

be functions so that ''g'' ○''f'' is a surjective function.

Give an example of sets ''A'', ''B'' and functions ''f'', ''g'' as above such that ''f'' is not surjective.
